title: Object-Oriented Programming
subject: CSE
description: Introduction to object-oriented software development using classes and objects. Covers abstraction, encapsulation, inheritance, and polymorphism.

title: Dynamic Web Fundamentals
subject: Web Design & Development
description: Covers core JavaScript and DOM manipulation for creating dynamic user interactions on websites.

title: Data Structures and Algorithms
subject: CSE
description: Covers abstract data types, recursive algorithms, and fundamental data structures such as stacks, queues, linked lists, trees, and graphs.

title: Religion
subject: Jesus Christ and His Evelasting Gospel A
description: This course focuses on Jesus Christ's eternal ministry, divine role, and teachings throughout His premortal, mortal, and postmortal life. The course emphasizes the Savior’s central role in Heavenly Father’s plan for His children. You are invited to deepen your love for and testimony of Jesus Christ and to become a more devoted disciple. This course is taught using blocks of scripture from the standard works in context (the Bible, Book of Mormon, Doctrine and Covenants, and the Pearl of Great Price) as well as the teachings of modern prophets. There is no textbook for this course.

title: Applied Associate Generals & Religion (BYU-Idaho) v2024
subject: Writing in Professional Contexts
description: A foundational course exploring discipleship and gospel-centered academic development.

title: Web & Computer Programming v2021SP
subject: Web Frontend Development I
description: This course builds on prior experience with Dynamic Web Fundamentals and programming. Students will focus on user experience, accessibility, compliance, performance optimization, and basic API usage.
prerequisites: Take the following: WDD131 - Dynamic Web Fundamentals (2) CSE111 - Programming with Functions (2)

title: Applied Associate Generals
subject: Math for the Real World
description: MATH 108X introduces the quantitative reasoning process. This process teaches you to use algebraic, computational, statistical, and graphical tools to make informed decisions about financial, family, social, and community issues. MATH 108X will satisfy the BYU-Idaho Foundations quantitative reasoning requirement, but it does not serve as a prerequisite for college algebra, trigonometry, or calculus-based courses.

title: Applied Associate Generals & Religion (BYU-Idaho) v2024
subject: Advanced Writing in Professional Context
description: Advanced Writing in Professional Contexts introduces you to the fundamentals of rhetorical principles and writing practices using a number of typical business situations. During the course, you will produce effective business letters, reports, and employment packages. This will prepare you for the demands of careers that require significant time reading, drafting, and revising written communication.

title: Web Frontend Development II
subject: Web Frontend Development II
description: This course is designed to give students the skills required to create web applications using HTML, CSS , and JavaScript. It is intended to help the student learn to do this without the aid of third-party frameworks or libraries. Because of this, the course focuses on how to solve larger, ill-structured business problems by designing and creating web applications.
prerequisites: WDD 230 - It is expected that you have learned and mastered the information made available to you in WDD 230 and its prerequisite courses. If you feel rusty, the following is a more specific list of topics you would have been introduced to in those courses that will be important that you are comfortable with, and some sources to use for review before the course begins.

title: Web Backend Development
subject: Web Backend Development
description: This class will focus on designing software systems at the largest possible level. An emphasis will be placed on problem solving, analysis skills, and interpersonal social skills.

title: Introduction to Databases
subject: Introduction to Databases
description: This course teaches the basic elements of database management systems. It introduces students to the concepts of logical and physical relationships in a data model and the concept of inner join. Students will use a computer aided software engineering (CASE) tool to design, create and query a database.
prerequisites: There are no pre-requisites for this course

title: Web Engineering
subject: Web Services
description: Full-stack web development including server-side technologies, RESTful APIs, authentication, and deployment.

title: Operating Systems
subject: CSE
description: Introduction to operating system principles including process management, memory management, and file systems.

title: Web Development
subject: Web Full-Stack Development
description: Culminating project demonstrating frontend and backend skills through a comprehensive web application.

title: Internship
subject: Web Design & Development
description: Professional internship experience in the web development industry.
